physDesc.p: The letter consists of one sheet of paper with typewriting on both sides. At the top of the back side is “R.A.” in the left corner and the date in the right. There appears to be a watermark on the paper, but it is unreadable under the text.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have received your letter telling me that Flint made the changes, in the article on me, himself, and I hereby apologize most sincerely for scolding you or having done it. Of course, you were quite right to make Flint take out the personal remarks. I did not like them at all, and regretted that I had no authority to take them out before the article was printed in “The Little Review.” I do, however, feel that Flint has shown rather poor taste, and a very slight lack of psychology, by taking out praise of my book which he had originally put in, and which he knew I had already seen in his first draft of the article. But I should not have assumed that it was you who did it, and I am very sorry.

I am beginning to think that perhaps I made a mistake about Brown. I thought he was honest, but I don’t at all like the way he is holding up your book. And Mr. Braithwaite told me last night he manages his affairs so badly that he practically does not get his books sold in the bookshops at all, and I think I shall be obliged to take your book away. I don’t know how to make it up to you. I shall do my best and see what can be done; but I really think it must be taken out of Brown’s hands. I am awfully sorry, and I feel very badly about it; but, of course, I supposed it would be all right – though I knew he wasn’t very well off.

Our book is in the press, and they expect to bring it out the first or second week in April. I think it should be very good. Please forget the things I said about your blue-penciling of the article, and remember how differently things sound, coming across the Atlantic.
I am sending you a little book of parodies by Louis Untermeyer, which I think is most amusing. And I am writing Hilda about the royalties.
Hilda says to address you at “The Egoist”, so I suppose you are leaving Hampton. Please send me your new address as soon as possible.

div.note: Aldington ultimately publishes his book, Images, Old and New (1916), with Edmund R. Brown's press, Four Seas.
